grape___Grape___Black_rot.name: Grape Black Rot
grape___Grape___Black_rot.symptoms: Small, brown spots on leaves that expand and develop black margins. Infected grapes shrivel and turn into hard, black 'mummies'.
grape___Grape___Black_rot.causes: Caused by the fungus Guignardia bidwellii. Wet, warm conditions promote infection.
grape___Grape___Black_rot.disease_cycle: Overwinters in mummified fruits and old canes. Rain splashes spread spores to new shoots and fruits during spring and summer.
grape___Grape___Black_rot.care_treatment: Prune and destroy infected material. Apply early-season fungicide sprays. Promote air circulation by proper vine spacing.

grape___Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).name: Grape Esca (Black Measles)
grape___Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).symptoms: Interveinal yellowing and scorching of leaves. Berries show dark spots, shrivel, and dry on the vine.
grape___Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).causes: Caused by a complex of fungi including Phaeomoniella chlamydospora. Wounds from pruning can facilitate infection.
grape___Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).disease_cycle: Fungi infect through pruning wounds and colonize the vascular system. Symptoms worsen over several seasons.
grape___Grape___Esca_(Black_Measles).care_treatment: Avoid large pruning wounds. Remove infected vines if severe. Some systemic fungicides may help but control is difficult.

grape___Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_.name: Grape Leaf Blight (Isariopsis Leaf Spot)
grape___Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_.symptoms: Brown, angular lesions on grape leaves, often leading to early defoliation.
grape___Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_.causes: Caused by the fungus Pseudocercospora vitis (formerly Isariopsis). Moist, humid environments encourage disease spread.
grape___Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_.disease_cycle: Spores are produced on infected leaves and spread by wind and rain. New infections occur throughout the growing season.
grape___Grape___Leaf_blight_(Isariopsis_.care_treatment: Apply protective fungicides during humid periods. Remove fallen infected leaves to reduce inoculum.

potato___Potato___Early_blight.name: Potato Early Blight
potato___Potato___Early_blight.symptoms: Small brown lesions with concentric rings on leaves. Older leaves yellow and drop prematurely.
potato___Potato___Early_blight.causes: Caused by the fungus Alternaria solani. Stress factors like drought or poor nutrition can worsen outbreaks.
potato___Potato___Early_blight.disease_cycle: Overwinters in soil or debris. Spores are dispersed by wind and rain to infect new plants.
potato___Potato___Early_blight.care_treatment: Use resistant varieties. Apply fungicides early. Maintain proper plant nutrition and avoid water stress.

potato___Potato___Late_blight.name: Potato Late Blight
potato___Potato___Late_blight.symptoms: Large, irregularly shaped water-soaked lesions on leaves, stems, and tubers; white mold under humid conditions.
potato___Potato___Late_blight.causes: Caused by the oomycete Phytophthora infestans, favored by cool and wet weather.
potato___Potato___Late_blight.disease_cycle: Spores spread rapidly through rain and wind, causing epidemics in wet conditions.
potato___Potato___Late_blight.care_treatment: Destroy infected plants. Apply protective fungicides before expected rain. Plant certified disease-free seed potatoes.

potato___Potato___healthy.name: Healthy Potato Leaf
potato___Potato___healthy.symptoms: No visible signs of disease. Leaves are green, firm, and uniform.
potato___Potato___healthy.care_treatment: Maintain good crop hygiene, regular monitoring, and optimal nutrition.

tomato___Tomato___Bacterial_spot.name: Tomato Bacterial Spot
tomato___Tomato___Bacterial_spot.symptoms: Small, dark brown water-soaked spots on leaves, stems, and fruit. Can cause fruit blemishes and leaf loss.
tomato___Tomato___Bacterial_spot.causes: Caused by Xanthomonas species. Spread favored by warm, wet weather.
tomato___Tomato___Bacterial_spot.disease_cycle: Bacteria overwinter in plant debris and seeds. Splashing water spreads bacteria to healthy tissues.
tomato___Tomato___Bacterial_spot.care_treatment: Use certified disease-free seed. Apply copper-based bactericides. Practice crop rotation.

tomato___Tomato___Early_blight.name: Tomato Early Blight
tomato___Tomato___Early_blight.symptoms: Brown circular lesions with concentric rings on lower leaves. Defoliation and poor fruit development follow.
tomato___Tomato___Early_blight.causes: Caused by the fungus Alternaria solani. Humid conditions favor spread.
tomato___Tomato___Early_blight.disease_cycle: Spores overwinter in debris and infect plants in moist conditions, spreading via wind and rain.
tomato___Tomato___Early_blight.care_treatment: Apply fungicides preventively. Maintain plant vigor and spacing. Remove plant debris.

tomato___Tomato___Late_blight.name: Tomato Late Blight
tomato___Tomato___Late_blight.symptoms: Dark, greasy lesions on leaves and stems. Fruit may show brown rot with a white mold under humid conditions.
tomato___Tomato___Late_blight.causes: Caused by Phytophthora infestans. Cool, wet weather accelerates outbreaks.
tomato___Tomato___Late_blight.disease_cycle: Rapid spread by airborne spores under moist conditions.
tomato___Tomato___Late_blight.care_treatment: Remove infected plants immediately. Use fungicide sprays during cool, rainy periods.

tomato___Tomato___Leaf_Mold.name: Tomato Leaf Mold
tomato___Tomato___Leaf_Mold.symptoms: Yellow spots on upper leaf surfaces, olive-green mold underneath. Severe cases cause leaf drop.
tomato___Tomato___Leaf_Mold.causes: Caused by the fungus Passalora fulva. High humidity inside greenhouses favors the disease.
tomato___Tomato___Leaf_Mold.disease_cycle: Spores spread through air and water. Survives in greenhouse debris.
tomato___Tomato___Leaf_Mold.care_treatment: Increase air circulation. Use resistant varieties. Apply fungicides in greenhouse crops.

tomato___Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.name: Tomato Septoria Leaf Spot
tomato___Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.symptoms: Numerous small, dark spots with gray centers on leaves. Causes early defoliation and yield loss.
tomato___Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.causes: Caused by the fungus Septoria lycopersici. Moist, humid conditions favor outbreaks.
tomato___Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.disease_cycle: Spores are produced on infected tissue and spread by water splash.
tomato___Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.care_treatment: Rotate crops. Remove and destroy infected material. Apply appropriate fungicides.

tomato___Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spott.name: Tomato Spider Mites (Two-Spotted)
tomato___Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spott.symptoms: Fine stippling on leaves, yellowing, bronzing, and webbing in severe cases.
tomato___Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spott.causes: Caused by the tiny pest Tetranychus urticae (two-spotted spider mite). Hot, dry conditions encourage outbreaks.
tomato___Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spott.disease_cycle: Eggs laid on undersides of leaves hatch and develop rapidly under warm temperatures.
tomato___Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spott.care_treatment: Spray with miticides or insecticidal soap. Increase humidity. Use predatory mites for biological control.

tomato___Tomato___Target_Spot.name: Tomato Target Spot
tomato___Tomato___Target_Spot.symptoms: Brown lesions with concentric rings resembling a target. Affects leaves, stems, and fruit.
tomato___Tomato___Target_Spot.causes: Caused by the fungus Corynespora cassiicola.
tomato___Tomato___Target_Spot.disease_cycle: Spores spread by wind and water, especially under humid conditions.
tomato___Tomato___Target_Spot.care_treatment: Apply fungicides preventively. Maintain good field sanitation.

tomato___Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Cur.name: Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus
tomato___Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Cur.symptoms: Severe leaf curling, yellowing, and stunted plant growth. Reduces fruit set and quality.
tomato___Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Cur.causes: Caused by Tomato yellow leaf curl virus (TYLCV), transmitted by whiteflies.
tomato___Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Cur.disease_cycle: Whiteflies acquire and transmit the virus while feeding.
tomato___Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Cur.care_treatment: Use resistant varieties. Control whiteflies with insecticides and barriers.

tomato___Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.name: Tomato Mosaic Virus
tomato___Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.symptoms: Mottled light and dark green areas on leaves, leaf curling, and reduced fruit yield.
tomato___Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.causes: Caused by Tomato mosaic virus (ToMV), a highly stable virus spread by mechanical contact.
tomato___Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.disease_cycle: Spread by contaminated tools, hands, and infected seeds.
tomato___Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.care_treatment: Disinfect tools. Use virus-free seed. Remove infected plants immediately.

tomato___Tomato___healthy.name: Healthy Tomato Leaf
tomato___Tomato___healthy.symptoms: âœ… No disease detected. Leaves appear green, strong, and vigorous.
tomato___Tomato___healthy.care_treatment: Maintain proper crop care and hygiene practices.
